item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on Crackdown in Egypt
item.description: The Lede is following events in Egypt on Saturday, where Islamist protesters have taken to the streets again to demonstrate against the military-backed government that killed hundreds this week.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Mostafa Hegazi, a political adviser and spokesman for Egypt’s interim president, Adli Mansour, spoke at the presidential palace in Cairo on Saturday.

item.title: A Secret Race for Abandoned Nuclear Material
item.description: Over a period of 17 years, Russian and American scientists collaborated to remove hundreds of pounds of plutonium and highly enriched uranium from a nuclear test site in Kazakhstan.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Soldiers near the center of the former Soviet nuclear test site in Semipalatinsk, Kazakhstan.

item.title: The Lede: Aug. 16 Updates on Protests in Egypt
item.description: The Lede is following events in Egypt on Friday, where Islamist protesters have taken to the streets to demonstrate against the military-backed government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Pressure by U.S. Failed to Sway Egypt’s Leaders
item.description: For President Obama, the violent crackdown has left him in a no-win position: risk a partnership that has been the bedrock of Middle East peace for 35 years, or stand by while longtime allies try to hold on to power by mowing down opponents.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK, PETER BAKER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Police officers moved into the Fateh mosque in Cairo during clashes on Saturday with supporters of the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi.

item.title: Standoff Erupts at a Mosque in Cairo as Egypt Falls Further Into Violence
item.description: Riot police stood guard outside a mosque where Islamist protesters were sheltering Saturday, deepening the sense that Egypt was descending into anarchy.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Supporters of the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, waited by a barricaded door inside the Fateh Mosque in Cairo on Saturday.

item.title: Prominent Advocate Held in Southern China
item.description: Yang Maodong, better known by his pen name, Guo Feixiong, is the second well-known member of China’s “rights defense” movement to be arrested in recent weeks.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Blood and Chaos Prevail in Egypt, Testing Control
item.description: Egypt erupted into chaos on Friday, raising doubts about the authorities’ capacity to maintain order, as opponents of the military takeover fought security forces and civilians in the street.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A supporter of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, prayed as a wounded friend was treated in Ramses Square in Cairo.

item.title: Layoffs Taboo, Japan Workers Are Sent to the Boredom Room
item.description: Facing a sluggish economy and increasing competition, Japan’s prime minister and major companies want to reduce longstanding restrictions on dismissing full-time workers.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miwako Sato joined Sony right out of high school in 1974.

item.title: Political Memo: Attacks on Protesters in Cairo Were Calculated to Provoke, Some Say
item.description: The ferocity of the attacks appears to have been a deliberate calculation of the military-appointed government to provoke violence from the Muslim Brotherhood and its allies, historians said Friday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Egyptian military guarding the remains of the Rabaa al-Adawiya mosque in Cairo, near which Islamist supporters of Mohamed Morsi had staged their protest.

item.title: Business Briefing | Legal News: Swiss Lawyer Pleads Guilty to Conspiracy in Tax Fraud
item.description: A Swiss lawyer accused of helping American clients conceal millions of dollars in offshore accounts pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit tax fraud in federal court in New York.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Thrust Into Nonstop Turmoil, an Obama Adviser Counsels Pragmatism
item.description: Susan E. Rice, in her six weeks as national security adviser, has dealt with a terrorist scare, deteriorating relations with Russia and, now, the chaos in Egypt.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Susan E. Rice, left, seen in the White House Rose Garden in June, has been on the job as national security adviser for six weeks.

item.title: Hezbollah Makes Vow to Step Up Sunni Fight
item.description: Hasan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, accused radical Sunnis of orchestrating a car bombing that killed 24 in Beirut.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Shiite Muslims gathered Friday for a televised speech by Hasan Nasrallah, Hezbollah's leader.

item.title: Two English Cities Battle in Court to Acquire Remains of King Richard III
item.description: The University of Leicester had laid plans for Richard’s re-internment based on a government license, but champions of York argued that the city was the king’s preferred burial place.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:credit: University of Leicester, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The skeleton of King Richard III was unearthed beneath a municipal parking lot late last year.

item.title: News Analysis: Ties With Egypt Army Constrain Washington
item.description: With the myriad, though largely invisible, ways the Egyptian military assists United States interests in the region, Egyptian generals have some leverage in facing Washington and its pressure to end a crackdown.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Democracy in Egypt Can Wait
item.description: The United States should back off from its zealous promotion of democracy in Egypt and the broader Middle East.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CHARLES A. KUPCHAN

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Government Warplanes Strike Rebel-Held District in Contested City
item.description: The strike killed at least 15 people and wounding dozens of others, activists said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Pistorius to Face New Gun Charges
item.description: The new charges involve accusations that Oscar Pistorius discharged a weapon in a restaurant in January and also fired a gun from a car while driving home from a vacation.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Court Approves Vasectomy for Disabled Man
item.description: A British court has ruled for the first time that a man who lacks the capacity to give informed consent should have a vasectomy because it is in his best interests.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: 24 Killed as Cargo Ship and Passenger Ferry Collide Off Coast
item.description: About 575 people were rescued by government vessels and small fishing boats by early Saturday morning, an official said.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechen Man on Trial in Killing Of Journalist Is Shot on Moscow Street
item.description: A Chechen man on trial for the murder of the journalist and government critic Anna Politkovskaya was shot in the leg, his lawyer said on Friday, calling it an attempt to silence him.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Bahrain: Police Put Down Prison Riot On Island, Injuring at Least 40 People
item.description: The authorities crushed a prison riot on Friday using stun grenades and tear gas, injuring at least 40 people, human rights groups said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: U.S. Troop Pullout Affects India-Pakistan Rivalry
item.description: Military exchanges between India and Pakistan over Kashmir point to a new brittleness: one exacerbated by the impending troop drawdown in Afghanistan, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: As Berlusconi’s Party Supports Embattled Chief, Critics Retaliate
item.description: Supporters of Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister, use billboards and banner-hauling planes to make their point, bringing politics to the air above beach resorts and inspiring a counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Party Drops Legal Dispute Over Election in Zimbabwe
item.description: The main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, said that it was withdrawing a court challenge because it did not think it would get a fair hearing.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Barred From Malaysia, but Still Connecting With Critical Jabs
item.description: Clare Rewcastle Brown, through the Internet and shortwave radio, has given voice to growing concerns among Malaysians about environmental degradation.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: “They can’t do this in Malaysia. They’d be arrested immediately, and their livelihoods would be destroyed,” Clare Rewcastle Brown said.
